title: (HackerOne SSO-SAML) Login CSRF, Open Redirect, and Self-XSS Possible Exploitation

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
###Summary:###

Login CSRF, Open Redirect, and Self-XSS Possible Exploitation through HackerOne SSO-SAML

###PoC###

- Go to █████;

Use a browser window with clear cookies.

Source-code:

```
<html>
<body>
	<iframe id="login_csrf_frame" src="████████" style="width:0;height:0;border:0;border:none;"></iframe>
	<script>
		setTimeout(function(){document.location.href = "https://hackerone.com/users/saml/sign_in?email=████&remember_me=true";}, 5000);
	</script>
</body>
</html>
```

###Impact:###

1) Information Leak

An attacker can use Logout CSRF + Login CSRF against a victim to steal all information sent by the victim to the HackerOne website while using the malicious session, including confidential bug reports.

2) Open Redirect

Since the SSO-SAML l​ogin flow can be started automatically (`GET https://hackerone.com/users/saml/sign_in?email=███`) by an attacker and it redirects to external URLs, the attacker can redirect the user to anywhere.

3) Self-XSS Possible Exploitation​

Some stored Self-XSS's (internal areas accessed just by the victim, etc.) can be exploited through Login CSRF.

```
Malicious page -> HackerOne Login CSRF -> Self-XSS triggers -> Logout -> Wait user actions
```

If the user interacts with the page (sign in with his account, etc.), the attacker can exploit the Self-XSS.

P.S.:

An attacker can add extra dots to the SAML Email Domain in the config dialog.
I didn't test all the implications, but registering a very similar domain could be a bad thing, like `hackerone..com`, `hackerone.com.`, `.hackerone.com` or even `gmail..com` because of typing mistakes (`victim@hackerone..com would redirect the victim to the attacker external login flow`).
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:

Login CSRF, Open Redirect, and Self-XSS Possible Exploitation through HackerOne SSO-SAML

PoC

  • Go to █████;

Use a browser window with clear cookies.

Source-code:

<html>
<body>
    <iframe id="login_csrf_frame" src="████████" style="width:0;height:0;border:0;border:none;"></iframe>
    <script>
        setTimeout(function(){document.location.href = "https://hackerone.com/users/saml/sign_in?email=████&remember_me=true";}, 5000);
    </script>
</body>
</html>

Impact:

1) Information Leak

An attacker can use Logout CSRF + Login CSRF against a victim to steal all information sent by the victim to the HackerOne website while using the malicious session, including confidential bug reports.

2) Open Redirect

Since the SSO-SAML l​ogin flow can be started automatically (GET https://hackerone.com/users/saml/sign_in?email=███) by an attacker and it redirects to external URLs, the attacker can redirect the user to anywhere.

3) Self-XSS Possible Exploitation​

Some stored Self-XSS's (internal areas accessed just by the victim, etc.) can be exploited through Login CSRF.

Malicious page -> HackerOne Login CSRF -> Self-XSS triggers -> Logout -> Wait user actions

If the user interacts with the page (sign in with his account, etc.), the attacker can exploit the Self-XSS.

P.S.:

An attacker can add extra dots to the SAML Email Domain in the config dialog.
I didn't test all the implications, but registering a very similar domain could be a bad thing, like hackerone..com, hackerone.com., .hackerone.com or even gmail..com because of typing mistakes (victim@hackerone..com would redirect the victim to the attacker external login flow).

activities.message: Hi @whhackersbr, thanks for your submission, we appreciate it! While investigating your submission, we couldn't figure out what the `iframe` element does exactly. Consider this: if Uber has SAML enabled through ███████, would any Uber employee be able to pull this off? Or do you need your own IDP or have really low security settings? Please elaborate how it works and we'll take another look. Thanks again!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @whhackersbr, thanks for your submission, we appreciate it! While investigating your submission, we couldn't figure out what the iframe element does exactly. Consider this: if Uber has SAML enabled through ███████, would any Uber employee be able to pull this off? Or do you need your own IDP or have really low security settings? Please elaborate how it works and we'll take another look. Thanks again!

activities.message:
Hey @bencode,

> (...) if Uber has SAML enabled through █████, would any Uber employee be able to pull this off?

No, just employees with privileges to change the Uber SAML IDP settings.

> (...) Please elaborate how it works and we'll take another look.

```

HackerOne starts SAML login flow without CSRF protection (opens ████████)
█████ starts another SAML login flow for corporate accounts (██████) without CSRF protection (opens ████)
███████ automatically signs in any user without password (returns to ██████)
██████████ Login CSRF (returns to HackerOne)
HackerOne Login CSRF

```
activities.markdown_message:

███████ automatically signs in any user without password (returns to ██████)
██████████ Login CSRF (returns to HackerOne)
HackerOne Login CSRF

activities.message:
@reed,

I saw that we need to pass through a review every time we change the config of the SSO-SAML.
What is done/considered in this review?
Depending on the answer I can or can not have more issues to report.
activities.markdown_message:
@reed,

I saw that we need to pass through a review every time we change the config of the SSO-SAML.
What is done/considered in this review?
Depending on the answer I can or can not have more issues to report.

activities.message:
Hey @whhackersbr,

I want to make sure I answered all your questions, let me know if I missed any!

> 1) Information Leak & 3) Self-XSS Possible Exploitation

We were unaware that you could create an account that has no password and that would auto-login without requiring user intervention, which does make it possible to achieve the CSRF. However, it seems that this isn't a great password strategy for a company to use. The reason we accept this risk is for the convenience of [IdP initiated SSO](https://docs.pingidentity.com/bundle/pf_sm_browserBasedSso_topic/page/task/idpInitiatedSsoPOST.html) as defined in the standard.

> 2) Open Redirect & PS extra dots in SAML email domain

The SAML URL and extra dots in the email domain is mitigated by (currently) a manual approval process. Our team verifies the SAML URLs before approving.

> What is done/considered in this review?

We do a few manual checks: 

**Domain** verification to ensure that the domain is valid and one that would only be controlled by the team.

**URL** checks that it's a recognized public service (ones [we support](https://support.hackerone.com/hc/en-us/articles/205587379)) or if it's an internal instance-for a team we trust, 

**Certificates** are looked at for expiration, ownership, etc.
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @whhackersbr,

I want to make sure I answered all your questions, let me know if I missed any!

1) Information Leak & 3) Self-XSS Possible Exploitation

We were unaware that you could create an account that has no password and that would auto-login without requiring user intervention, which does make it possible to achieve the CSRF. However, it seems that this isn't a great password strategy for a company to use. The reason we accept this risk is for the convenience of IdP initiated SSO as defined in the standard.

2) Open Redirect & PS extra dots in SAML email domain

The SAML URL and extra dots in the email domain is mitigated by (currently) a manual approval process. Our team verifies the SAML URLs before approving.

What is done/considered in this review?

We do a few manual checks:

Domain verification to ensure that the domain is valid and one that would only be controlled by the team.

URL checks that it's a recognized public service (ones we support) or if it's an internal instance-for a team we trust,

Certificates are looked at for expiration, ownership, etc.

activities.message:
@bencode @reed @security

Hey @bencode,

> I want to make sure I answered all your questions, let me know if I missed any!

No, you didn't miss anything.
Thanks.
=)

> 1) Information Leak & 3) Self-XSS Possible Exploitation
> (...) However, it seems that this isn't a great password strategy for a company to use. (...)

I agree, but this is a great strategy for an attacker, exactly to achieve the Info Leak and/or Self-XSS exploitation.

> (...) The reason we accept this risk is for the convenience of IdP initiated SSO as defined in the standard. (...)

But you can protect the users against the Login CSRF without breaking the feature.

> 2) Open Redirect & PS extra dots in SAML email domain
> The SAML URL and extra dots in the email domain is mitigated by (currently) a manual approval process. Our team verifies the SAML URLs before approving.

Perfect, the extra dots stuff are not exploitable.

I disagree about the Open Redirect mitigation since the review team would not know about it.

```
1) The attacker creates the following flow:
hackerone.com --(redirect)--> ████ --(redirect)--> corp.attacker.com asks for the password 
--(redirect)--> ██████ --(redirect)--> HackerOne

2) The attacker submits the application for approval.

3) The review team accepts the application.

4) The attacker changes the flow to:
hackerone.com --(redirect)--> ██████ --(redirect)--> corp.attacker.com --(redirect)--> Any Site
```

All the consequences of this Login CSRF (Info Leak, Open Redirect, and Self-XSS Exploitation) could be mitigated with CSRF protections, without breaking the SSO feature.

> We do a few manual checks:
Domain verification to ensure that the domain is valid and one that would only be controlled by the team.

How do you decide if a domain is only controlled by a team?
This is very important to me.

Thank you very much.
activities.markdown_message:

Thanks.
=)

(...) However, it seems that this isn't a great password strategy for a company to use. (...)

(...) The reason we accept this risk is for the convenience of IdP initiated SSO as defined in the standard. (...)

But you can protect the users against the Login CSRF without breaking the feature.

2) Open Redirect & PS extra dots in SAML email domain
The SAML URL and extra dots in the email domain is mitigated by (currently) a manual approval process. Our team verifies the SAML URLs before approving.

Perfect, the extra dots stuff are not exploitable.

I disagree about the Open Redirect mitigation since the review team would not know about it.

1) The attacker creates the following flow:
hackerone.com --(redirect)--> ████ --(redirect)--> corp.attacker.com asks for the password 
--(redirect)--> ██████ --(redirect)--> HackerOne

2) The attacker submits the application for approval.

3) The review team accepts the application.

4) The attacker changes the flow to:
hackerone.com --(redirect)--> ██████ --(redirect)--> corp.attacker.com --(redirect)--> Any Site

All the consequences of this Login CSRF (Info Leak, Open Redirect, and Self-XSS Exploitation) could be mitigated with CSRF protections, without breaking the SSO feature.

We do a few manual checks:
Domain verification to ensure that the domain is valid and one that would only be controlled by the team.

How do you decide if a domain is only controlled by a team?
This is very important to me.

Thank you very much.

activities.message:
Hey @whhackersbr,

We've discussed have some questions:

 - How do you propose we protect against the login CSRF without breaking IdP initiated SSO?
 - How would we validate that an IdP (malicious or not) doesn't change to a malicious redirect?

> How do you decide if a domain is only controlled by a team?

We use a mixture of OSINT, e-mail validation, domain validation and website validation.

Thanks,
@bencode
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @whhackersbr,

We've discussed have some questions:

  • How do you propose we protect against the login CSRF without breaking IdP initiated SSO?
  • How would we validate that an IdP (malicious or not) doesn't change to a malicious redirect?

How do you decide if a domain is only controlled by a team?

We use a mixture of OSINT, e-mail validation, domain validation and website validation.

Thanks,
@bencode

Hey @bencode,

I will provide a protection, but I am sorry because I am not a developer, so I will probably commit a lot of conceptual mistakes.
=(

Please guide me to the correct approach (security vs. usability).

PoC Video

  • https://youtu.be/%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88

SCENARIO 1

1) User inserts his corporate email in the HackerOne login form and clicks on "Sign in";

2) HackerOne performs a POST request with CSRF protection;

3) If everything is right, HackerOne sets a​ SAML SSO short life cookie with the user's email and redirects him to /users/saml/sign_in?email=user@domain.com;

4) /users/saml/sign_in?email=user@domain.com tests the cookie and the user's email, and if they are right, the user will be redirected to the regular SAML SSO flow, but ​if the cookie is missing or is wrong, user gets an error;

5) After the SAML SSO flow inside user's corporate network, he ends in /users/saml/auth;

6) /users/saml/auth tests the cookie, the user's email, and the SAML SSO credentials:

  • If everything is right, login successful (no friction);
  • If the credentials are right but cookie and email, a warning screen is shown asking if he wants to sign in with that email, and the login is performed through a POST with CSRF protection after the user's consent/click (small friction);
  • If nothing is right, the ​user gets an error (nothing changes).

SCENARIO 2

1) User goes to a malicious website;
2) The attacker sends a direct request to /users/saml/sign_in?email=attacker@domain.com;
3) /users/saml/sign_in returns an error because the SAML SSO cookie is missing or wrong​;

SCENARIO 3

1) User starts the SAML SSO flow outside the HackerOne platform;
2) User ends in /users/saml/auth;
3) The SAML SSO cookie is missing, so a warning screen is shown asking if he really wants to sign in with that email, and the login is performed through a POST with CSRF protection after the user's consent/click (small friction);

Thanks and sorry in anticipation for all the conceptual mistakes.
I know it is easy to find bugs but hard to fix accordingly.

PoC source code attached.​

activities.message: P.S.: For the "warning screen", you can create a `Remember me for X months` option to reduce the friction, using a cookie to know all accepted emails on that computer.
activities.markdown_message: P.S.: For the "warning screen", you can create a Remember me for X months option to reduce the friction, using a cookie to know all accepted emails on that computer.

activities.message:
Hey @whhackersbr,

We've discussed this again internally and have decided this is a not fix and we're happy to accept the risk. However, we were impressed by your reporting and PoC so we've decided we are going to award you some swag! Make sure your address is up to date in HackerOne so you receive it :)

Cheers,
@asuka

@whhackersbr,

Just to follow-up, we changed the SAML sign-up flow unrelated to your issues, as we're currently improving how we handle product edition changes, and SAML set-up was changed as a result of that work.

Secondly, we accept the risk of that for open redirect, as we require a company to sign-up and pay for Profesional edition or above before they can sign-up for SAML. How would we fix this issue anyway? We cannot control the third-party IdP.

activities.message:
@reed @security,

> Just to follow-up, we changed the SAML sign-up flow unrelated to your issues, as we're currently improving how we handle product edition changes, and SAML set-up was changed as a result of that work.

Oh, understood.
;-)

> How would we fix this issue anyway? We cannot control the third-party IdP.

This specific​ behavior can be fixed if you send `https://hackerone.com/users/saml/*` through the `External Link Warning`, currently, this URL bypasses the warning. You will still have the Open Redirector bug, but reports inside the H1 platform would not have URLs to malicious code that bypasses the warning.

> (...) this is a not fix (...)

Can you please tell me why my fix (Anti Login CSRF for SAML Login) doesn't work?
Sometimes I can fix the problem, who knows, hehehe.
=)

activities.message:
Hi @whhackersbr,

While we feel the risk of the open redirect being abused in URL comments is minimal at best, we do strive to go above and beyond and fix issues that could possibly be used in the future to chain exploits together (defense-in-depth strategy). We've ensured all auth-related endpoints are no longer exempt from the external link warning interstitial, as per your last comment, which should alleviate this concern.

We also discussed the Login CSRF inherit in IdP-initiated sessions with several other companies, and we continue to feel that bypassing CSRF checks is an accepted risk for the user experience of SSO via SAML. This may change in the future if this begins to be exploited somehow.

I think this covers everything you've mentioned, so let me know if I've missed something.

activities.message: Thank you for poking around at this code! We really appreciate it. I'm requesting public disclosure. Let me know if anything in your PoCs you want censored/removed, since I know it includes some of your personal accounts.
